Here's a tip for beginners: don't play this game!
It's just not worth the stress and mental sanity. Dark Souls is a game that's hard for the sake of being hard and nothing else.
Do yourself a favour and play Witcher 3 instead. You'll thank me later.

snippet.textDisplay:
My best general advice for beginners is 
1. Explore as much as you can
2. Try to stick to just a couple weapons
3. Careful how things you spread your stats
4. Take the open areas and dungeons very slowly, taking out enemies one at a time
5. USE SHIELDS shields are lifesavers in many situations, and learning to parry is also very worth it, plus some shields give passive buffs
6. This is mainly for people who started with elden ring or ds3, the roll timing is different in ds1, so take time to learn how to time rolls
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: First, get your resistance to 15. This will make it so that your sorcerer can survive a little longer in blighttown swamp. Next, get the return to the undead asylum and grab the rusted iron ring; it makes it so that walking in deep water or swamp is just like walking on dry ground. Third, always start as a pyromancer with the master key. Pyromancer armor set has the highest defense to weight ratio. Speaking of weight, take your equip weight and multiply by 4. You have two numbers for your equip load: a higher number and a lower one. If you multiply the lower number by 4 and it's more than a certain percentage of the bigger number, it will effect your travel speed. For example, if your equip weight limit says 40.0, the most you can equip is 9.9, which is under 25% of your equip weight. The full pyromancer set with the uchigatana and a shield like the grass crest shield will weigh 15.0, 25% of 60. Bring your endurance to 21 or wear a ring you can get to either artificially increase your endurance or a different ring to increase your weight limit.

You have two numbers for your equip load: a higher number and a lower one. The full pyromancer set with the uchigatana and a shield like the grass crest shield will weigh 15.0, 25% of 60. snippet.textDisplay:
I disagree with tip number 5. Having mid roll with high poise will always give you a ton more survivability as a beginner than fast rolling since you are not yet accustomed to the attack pattern of enemies. So equipping just 1 or 2 heavy armor pieces (Havel grieves and gloves being pretty standard) will allow you to shrug off almost all enemy attacks without getting staggered. This will give you more opportunities to attack and retreat, which will in turn facilitate ending fights faster.
 Alternatively, and this is a bit mot spoilery, there are a couple pieces of light armor with poise that you can combine with the wolf ring to raise your poise high enough to deal with most enemy attacks. Those being the chain mail chest piece and the hollow soldier waistcloth which together with the wolf ring will give you decent defense and 56 poise.

snippet.textDisplay: Whenever to go talk to any NPC, always take your fingers off the triggers and ALWAYS stand with your back to the NPC.  Face away from them unless you have to trigger another dialogue line.  It's incredibly easy to accidentally attack an NPC and you don't want to put your sword through the face of an important vendor or teacher.  You wouldn't believe the number of threads across hundreds of forums where people are saying "Help!  I accidentally killed [critical NPC]!"  Don't give yourself the opportunity to fuck up that badly.

snippet.textDisplay: Just a comment on resistance. Resistance only increases poison and nothing else. While you are leveling it may appear that resistance is increasing other stats but in actuality those other stats will all automatically increase when raising soul level via any stat. At very low levels it is true that resistance increases other stats, but as you increase soul Level all of those stats woudl be automatically raised just by increasing soul level. So the stats that you thought were being raised by resistance were actually being raised anyways just by leveling in any stat. So don't bother with resistance. The only appropriate time to invest in resistance is when all other stats are 99 except attunement which is 50. Just note, by SL 240 it takes around 500,000 souls to level so you need billions of souls before resistance is worth it.

snippet.textDisplay: His tip about not leveling is wrong, The cost will go up regardless and the downside of not being able to allocate points to other stats as easily is completely avoidable by not trying to spec as a jack of all trades. If you want to pvp just dont level past 120 or 125 and remember to use souls to buy and upgrade gear aside from that theres no major downside to leveling. Yeah the cost goes up and it gets harder to level but thats how leveling functions in any rpg. You dont hear people saying dont level past 20 in a final fantasy game because leveling will cost more. My advice pick a primary stat based on your class like strength for knight intelligence for mage faith for priest and then spend every other point or 3rd point on a utility stat like vitality or attunement    if your running as a spell caster and maybe throw 2 out of every 10 levels into endurance based on your needs. Ill agree resistances can be a dump stat but dont ignore leveling at the fear of it costing more as you progress you will gradually get more souls where 10k starts to seem like nothing. Other then that keep in mind the pvp general level and the higher your level relative to the general level of an area can make finding multiplayer signs harder if your 10 or more levels higher then other players.

snippet.textDisplay: best stat to upgrade is endurance. it increases your equip load and your stamina .... which enables you to wear better armor ... keeps you mobile ... and allows you to hit your foe one more time ... pick a weapon that is quick and hits hard ... the added bonus damage of bleed is a plus ... chaos weapons depend on humanity for their power ... die and your humanity is included in that blood puddle, rendering your powerful weapon useless ... dont go for humanity driven weapons ... stamina management is key here. master it early. in conclusion ... high defense ... high mobility ... high stamina ... +15 buffable weapon with added bleed should see you through a very enjoyable play through ... dont be afraid to grind for souls ... what you put in, you get out ... good luck ... Dark Souls is an incredible game. It will change your way of gaming for ever.

snippet.textDisplay: I couldn't disagree more about picking the master key on first run. Run #2 and on, absolutely. In my opinion, the master key can really ruin the flow/natural progression of the game for new players. I also think it can take away some of the magic of the interconnectedness of the world--It's so much more meaningful to push through a tough area, only to open up a mindboggling shortcut vs. just going through the shortcut backwards.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm just done with my first run through DS, and, speaking as someone who is a bit closer to the subject matter, here is my list of things I wish I had known before starting :
1. Starting class is not important, mechanically speaking, in the long run. That's not the same thing as it doesn't matter. The best class is the one that clicks for your playstyle, and that will affect your investment in the game. Try them all out in the Asylum and maybe a little way into the main game, then decide.
2. Don't immediately put any consumable you find in your quick item slots. Having to cycle back and forth between items can get you killed in combat. Actually scratch that, you can only cycle forth, at least on the PS4 version, which means that if you cycle past the item you wanted, you have to do a full circuit to come back to it. Not ideal under stress. For the vast majority of the game, you only need to carry your Estus flasks there anyway. Just switch in and out other items as needed for the area. Side note: In extreme situations, such as particularly grizzly boss fights, Humanity works as a full heal, and is a bit quicker to pull off, I feel. Keep that in mind for later in the game. Also, the game is a little janky in places, you can find yourself halfway down a cliff with nowhere to go but into the void, homeward bones can help in those situations, keep a few handy in inventory, but not on your quick item bar.
3. Make a flexible build. You're going to want options as you go along. Practically, that means putting 16 points in all the major damage stats (STR,DEX,INT,FTH), then pick your main damage stat and level that. Put 12 in Attunement giving you two spell slots, even if you're not a primary caster. For every two points you put into your main damage stat, put one into END and one into VIT. It's not what I did, but it's what I should have done.
4. Pick a weapon and stick with it is broadly good advice, but incomplete. Rather, level multiple weapons at the beginning of the game and try them out. Don't be afraid to change up your gear according to the area you're playing through. If you feel you're getting diminishing returns from your current weapon set, dump it. Grind a bit in the early areas to level all the weapons you're planning on using to +5. Later on, you should have a good idea what works well for you, and you can level that one further.
5. Try out all the move sets for any new weapon you get in a safe area, if you don't like it, chuck it in the bottomless box. In fact, anything you're not actively using, chuck it in the bottomless box. No point in cluttering up your inventory. The exceptions are some shields & some rings. Different shields & rings give varying amounts of damage resistance to different types of damage, or confer other bonuses, or block status effects. Keep a few on you to switch out according to what type of damage the enemies in a given area do. Keep a Ring of Sacrifice about your person at all times, if you're about to do something risky, pop it on, save yourself the grief. 
6. Get a ranged option that you can free aim early. That means a bow. Helps with cheesing, helps with drawing enemies from large groups. If you go with a DEX build, you can even do some damage with one later on. Crossbows are practically useless, don't bother. 
7. Unless you are a primary caster, offensive magic is best left for NG+. Use your slots for defensive or healing spells. Yes, you can build massively overpowered AOE nukers or single target damage dealers if you know what you're doing, but you won't, so you'll end up with a seriously underpowered glass cannon, without the cannon part. As a side note, being a primary caster on your first playthrough, not a good idea. Feasible, but not a good idea. 
8. If you have the option to summon for a boss fight, do it. If you have the option to cheese a boss, do it. Chivalry has it's place in Dark Souls. That place is on the corpse you picked clean two rooms back. NPC summons often unlock special items and gear later in the game too.
9. TURN PVP OFF. It's broken in so many little ways that leave it ripe for exploitation. Honestly, I'd just leave it off unless you're really into having some twatsander in late game gear come and gank you while you're just trying to get through the game for the first time, and why wouldn't you be? I'm sure there's a community of like-minded players who just want to have good wholesome fun somewhere out there buried under layers and layers of giantdad builds, chaos pyros and dark bead spammers, but all I've ever met were wankers. This also cuts off your player summons, but you can get by with NPC summons.
10. Don't kill any NPC's you don't have to, especially not early on. The rewards are rarely worth the grief. The one exception being Lautrec. Kick that bellend off the cliff as soon as he gets to Firelink. You can do his quest in NG+.
11. The four status effects are Curse: Very deadly, but very rare, not really worth worrying about except in one boss battle, arguably. Bleed: annoying in the early game, but not very deadly, can pretty safely be ignored. Poison: Very annoying in the early game, but becomes negligible by the late game, you're going to want some protection against this. Toxin: Super annoying in the early game, but also very rare outside of one area. Luckily, most the same protection against poison works against Toxin, for the most part.
12. Learn to kick reliably. Learn to backstab reliably. Learn to parry reliably. In fact, make one of your usual carry shields the target shield, that'll give you a larger parry window. Practice these in an open area or against weaker enemies.
13. Equipment weight is going to be a major concern early on. Avoid heavy armor and weapons until later, and arguably, even then. I find it's rarely worth the trade off in mobility and DPS, but that's a bit dependent on your build, so feel free to ignore that advice.
14. Don't get careless. Heal up often, advance slowly with your shield up. Until you learn where the enemies are, assume that they're everywhere. If there's a sharp turn, assume there's an enemy hiding behind it. If there's an angle you can't see, assume there's an enemy lurking there. If there's an open space ahead, assume there's an ambush. If an enemy runs away, assume he's trying to lure you into a trap. Leeroy Jenkinses will not get far in Dark Souls, there's even a reference to that later in the game, in case you hadn't gotten the message by then.
15. The Master Key. It's useful, but it's only really useful if you're using a guide. The main reason to choose it as a starting gift is that the other starting gifts are a bit crap. I'd just go with the Thief class and get a different item like the Black Fire Bombs or the Divine Blessing potion if you want it.
snippet.textOriginal:
I'm just done with my first run through DS, and, speaking as someone who is a bit closer to the subject matter, here is my list of things I wish I had known before starting :
1. Starting class is not important, mechanically speaking, in the long run. That's not the same thing as it doesn't matter. The best class is the one that clicks for your playstyle, and that will affect your investment in the game. Try them all out in the Asylum and maybe a little way into the main game, then decide.
2. Don't immediately put any consumable you find in your quick item slots. Having to cycle back and forth between items can get you killed in combat. Actually scratch that, you can only cycle forth, at least on the PS4 version, which means that if you cycle past the item you wanted, you have to do a full circuit to come back to it. Not ideal under stress. For the vast majority of the game, you only need to carry your Estus flasks there anyway. Just switch in and out other items as needed for the area. Side note: In extreme situations, such as particularly grizzly boss fights, Humanity works as a full heal, and is a bit quicker to pull off, I feel. Keep that in mind for later in the game. Also, the game is a little janky in places, you can find yourself halfway down a cliff with nowhere to go but into the void, homeward bones can help in those situations, keep a few handy in inventory, but not on your quick item bar.
3. Make a flexible build. You're going to want options as you go along. Practically, that means putting 16 points in all the major damage stats (STR,DEX,INT,FTH), then pick your main damage stat and level that. Put 12 in Attunement giving you two spell slots, even if you're not a primary caster. For every two points you put into your main damage stat, put one into END and one into VIT. It's not what I did, but it's what I should have done.
4. Pick a weapon and stick with it is broadly good advice, but incomplete. Rather, level multiple weapons at the beginning of the game and try them out. Don't be afraid to change up your gear according to the area you're playing through. If you feel you're getting diminishing returns from your current weapon set, dump it. Grind a bit in the early areas to level all the weapons you're planning on using to +5. Later on, you should have a good idea what works well for you, and you can level that one further.
5. Try out all the move sets for any new weapon you get in a safe area, if you don't like it, chuck it in the bottomless box. In fact, anything you're not actively using, chuck it in the bottomless box. No point in cluttering up your inventory. The exceptions are some shields & some rings. Different shields & rings give varying amounts of damage resistance to different types of damage, or confer other bonuses, or block status effects. Keep a few on you to switch out according to what type of damage the enemies in a given area do. Keep a Ring of Sacrifice about your person at all times, if you're about to do something risky, pop it on, save yourself the grief. 
6. Get a ranged option that you can free aim early. That means a bow. Helps with cheesing, helps with drawing enemies from large groups. If you go with a DEX build, you can even do some damage with one later on. Crossbows are practically useless, don't bother. 
7. Unless you are a primary caster, offensive magic is best left for NG+. Use your slots for defensive or healing spells. Yes, you can build massively overpowered AOE nukers or single target damage dealers if you know what you're doing, but you won't, so you'll end up with a seriously underpowered glass cannon, without the cannon part. As a side note, being a primary caster on your first playthrough, not a good idea. Feasible, but not a good idea. 
8. If you have the option to summon for a boss fight, do it. If you have the option to cheese a boss, do it. Chivalry has it's place in Dark Souls. That place is on the corpse you picked clean two rooms back. NPC summons often unlock special items and gear later in the game too.
9. TURN PVP OFF. It's broken in so many little ways that leave it ripe for exploitation. Honestly, I'd just leave it off unless you're really into having some twatsander in late game gear come and gank you while you're just trying to get through the game for the first time, and why wouldn't you be? I'm sure there's a community of like-minded players who just want to have good wholesome fun somewhere out there buried under layers and layers of giantdad builds, chaos pyros and dark bead spammers, but all I've ever met were wankers. This also cuts off your player summons, but you can get by with NPC summons.
10. Don't kill any NPC's you don't have to, especially not early on. The rewards are rarely worth the grief. The one exception being Lautrec. Kick that bellend off the cliff as soon as he gets to Firelink. You can do his quest in NG+.
11. The four status effects are Curse: Very deadly, but very rare, not really worth worrying about except in one boss battle, arguably. Bleed: annoying in the early game, but not very deadly, can pretty safely be ignored. Poison: Very annoying in the early game, but becomes negligible by the late game, you're going to want some protection against this. Toxin: Super annoying in the early game, but also very rare outside of one area. Luckily, most the same protection against poison works against Toxin, for the most part.
12. Learn to kick reliably. Learn to backstab reliably. Learn to parry reliably. In fact, make one of your usual carry shields the target shield, that'll give you a larger parry window. Practice these in an open area or against weaker enemies.
13. Equipment weight is going to be a major concern early on. Avoid heavy armor and weapons until later, and arguably, even then. I find it's rarely worth the trade off in mobility and DPS, but that's a bit dependent on your build, so feel free to ignore that advice.
14. Don't get careless. Heal up often, advance slowly with your shield up. Until you learn where the enemies are, assume that they're everywhere. If there's a sharp turn, assume there's an enemy hiding behind it. If there's an angle you can't see, assume there's an enemy lurking there. If there's an open space ahead, assume there's an ambush. If an enemy runs away, assume he's trying to lure you into a trap. Leeroy Jenkinses will not get far in Dark Souls, there's even a reference to that later in the game, in case you hadn't gotten the message by then.
15. The Master Key. It's useful, but it's only really useful if you're using a guide. The main reason to choose it as a starting gift is that the other starting gifts are a bit crap. I'd just go with the Thief class and get a different item like the Black Fire Bombs or the Divine Blessing potion if you want it.

snippet.textDisplay: Bandit is the most underrated class in the entire series. You never see anyone choose it and I don't know why. It wields a battle axe which is a pretty high damage weapon starting out as well as a shield with poison resistance. It has one of the highest strengths of all the classes and the vitality and dexterity are also quite high so it's a perfect class to go for if you're going for a quality build. Without heavy armour it's also quite agile and any self respecting Souls fan will tell you that agility trumps defence.

snippet.textDisplay:
Additional Tips for Beginners:

1. Learn to adapt to every situation. You may have limited/restricted usage to some of the in-game items, but you can use most of them for your playthrough. Try experimenting if you find yourself stuck. Each one is *unique* so try utilizing them to specific situations.

2. Every enemy has a *weakness* that can be exploited. Try to be observant.

3. Maintain your composure. Your character is not a superhero and is bound by *restrictions* . Try not to be reckless. Every move is crucial.

4. Prepare to die and lose *something* . A lot. Do not get attached to those that you have already lost. Let them go and move forward.

5. The city of Lordran may be unforgiving, but remember that you are not alone in the game. You can always get some sort of *help* . You just have to look or it.

6. *Don't give up.*


*Additional:
-Play blindly for your first playthrough. I cannot stress this enough if you want to have the best experience and feel satisfaction once the credit rolls.

snippet.textDisplay: Hey, I Know I'm late to the party but I had to get this out. Do not get the Master Key as a starting item when you are new to the game. You will get lost and you will end up in overly frustrating areas. Don't make it harder as it needs to be on your first playthrough.
snippet.textOriginal: Hey, I Know I'm late to the party but I had to get this out. Do not get the Master Key as a starting item when you are new to the game. You will get lost and you will end up in overly frustrating areas. Don't make it harder as it needs to be on your first playthrough.

snippet.textDisplay:
1. Don't pick the master key on your first run. You're more likely to end up in the wrong area with it than find better loot. 
2. When the guy at firelink tells you the second bell is below, he's not talking about the catacombs.
3.Patience is the best skill to level. You will need tons of it.

snippet.textDisplay:
DO NOT TAKE THE MASTER KEY ON YOUR FIRST RUN

In your description of why to pick the master key, you basically demonstrate why *NO first time player should EVER pick the master key*. It gets you into higher level areas before a first time player will almost ever be ready for it, and as you said it can literally sequence break your game which can make knowing what you're supposed to do very difficult if you're going in blind.

snippet.textDisplay:
Best tip: roll warrior, use your starting souls to get to +16str, yolo into catacombs and join gravelord covenant to get gravelord sword = pretty nicely set up til O&S (but there you can nuke the giant blacksmith and use his wep). With gravelord sword you also can run around murdering black knights - probably would prefer one of their weps if you're lucky enough :)
Also, if you bother to wear armour, wear stuff that gives you good poison/fire resist. Only for Nito and 4Kings might you consider actually bulking up on physical resist gear. Recommend thief gear (lower undead burg - light but solid), pyro gear (blighttown swamp - poison resist), gold-hemmed gear (demon ruins - fire resist), or stone guardian gear (darkroot forest - physical resist). Or if you are REALLY gangster grab the velka and painted guardian sets from the painted world - fashion souls baby :)
Always take grass crest shield; take the longbow nearby as well; rings would be a big block of text so you all can figure that out yourself, but havel is always a good bet and FAP ring is a practically a cheat :)

snippet.textDisplay: Pyromancy is always best. It starts out with the lowest soul level, so you can immediately put points into what you need and not bother with stats you don’t need. It’s also lighter than a knight, and tankier than a sorcerer, while also allowing decent melee and access to range options with no stat investment. I always recommend Pyromancer for noobs.

snippet.textDisplay:
My Tips for Begginers which I follow up to this day.
1. Never one hand heavy or slow weapons like Zweihander, it makes your attacks akward and leaves you more open even against slow enemies. If you must use a shield Carry a a lighter weapon to be paired with shield.
2. Always carry a shorter weapon. Channel your inner Goblin Slayer. If you are in a tight spot, go for a shorter weapon to prevent yourself from attacking walls rather than an enemy if you cannot go to a wider space.
3. Patience, I cannot stress this enough. Channel your ways of killing bosses in MonHun games into ordinary enemies here as they will and can kill you. Amp that up by Ten for Bosses.
4. Be pragmatic about fighting. Chivalry and Honor are not in this game.

snippet.textDisplay:
#1 and #2 tips are terrible
If this is a "Top 10 tips for BEGINNERS" then classes matters a LOT. It's true that you can be anything later in the game, you can start as a sorcerer and suddenly become a knight, BUT the initial stats are different, and beginners can struggle a lot because of a few skill points.
Also GETTING THE MASTER KEY IS A FREAKING TERRIBLE ADVICE!! This will allow players to enter places where they shouldn't be, they can be in a lot more difficult places, face stronger enemies, get lost, get frustrated, give up playing the game... so it's better to get the Tiny Ring or Black Firebombs

snippet.textDisplay: Following up the video: the starting class in dark souls has the touch of different points numbers. Pyromancer and wanderer both got tied the mos stats to their level(84 per level one) if you intend to do a very high level char(as vynil said, its only recomended to overlevel if you are willing farm for the expensive souls for high levels, because you dont want to run out of souls for other soending tasks like upgrading weapons and buying new spells) theyre nice, as you will have to grind 1-4 levels less than other classes. Sorcerer got a best farm and consistent damage early, and cleric can join the sunbros covenant with fewer level ups. Deprived wastes less points in most builds, so it feels better. And thief gets the master key by default, which allows you to grab another gift(all useless overrall but i want old witch ring for roleplaying purposes) Late game wise it really doesnt matter, but pyro's, sorcerer and cleric early game is overall healthier and more op, though pyromancies gets really garbage if you dont rush the depths to upgrade the flame

snippet.textDisplay:
Actual tips for beginners.
1 Starting class matters a lot for noobs. Knight or sorceror.
2 Always pick tiny beings ring. A little extra hp helps a lot untill you learn.
5 stay under 50% equip load. Mobility > defense but until you learn when to roll etc. Youre gonna want the defense.
6 pick TWO weapons and stick with them. One for long range one for close combat.
11 once you find the grass crest shield and ring of favor NEVER TAKE THEM OFF. The ring breaks if you do, and both are just so good you dont want anything else.
12 always kindle bonfires. Theyll give more estus when resting that way. 
13 you dont have to kill everything, but stopping to grind for souls levels and items can help significantly. 
14 be patient. Dont button mash like a kingdom hearts game. 1 or 2 hits then back off. If you get greedy, you get smashed in the face. 
15 fight dirty. Cheese enemies from outside their reach. Hit and run. Use falling attacks for huge damage. Use ANY trick to win.

snippet.textDisplay:
For a beginner's pure strength character, I would recommend choosing a knight and picking the black firebombs as your gift, upon first meeting the asylum demon, keep your distance and eat at it's health. Once it dies you'll receive the demon great hammer.

Alternately, pick the master key, kill AD normally, and make your way to blighttown through the drake valley, go to the far side (right of quelaag entrance) and grab the great club for a good early str weapon.
snippet.textOriginal:
For a beginner's pure strength character, I would recommend choosing a knight and picking the black firebombs as your gift, upon first meeting the asylum demon, keep your distance and eat at it's health. Once it dies you'll receive the demon great hammer.

Alternately, pick the master key, kill AD normally, and make your way to blighttown through the drake valley, go to the far side (right of quelaag entrance) and grab the great club for a good early str weapon.

snippet.textDisplay:
Playing right now, the only tip I would give is = take your time.

In the fight, analyse the opponent movement and attack only when you're sure.
In the environment, take the time to explore, try different routes. If a route seems completely impossible even though you passed the previous one without much issues, chances are this is not the right way.
Take the time to talk to the PNJ, more than one time. They will teach you important things about the lore and items of the game.

At the beginning, I couldn't understand how to use magic, even though I had everything to. But the more I play, the more I explore, the more I talk to the PNJ and the more I read items descriptions, the more I understand that everything I need to know is explained in the game. You just need to take the time to see it.

snippet.textDisplay: OH AND HEY! Helpful tip I learned in Demons Souls which I assume will carry over: DON'T HOLD UP YOUR SHIELD AFTER A BLOCK!!!! Your stamina recovers much more slowly with the shield up. Pay attention or dodge out of the way and keep the shield down until you have 75-80% stamina back, otherwise another hit may break apart your stamina and cut through the shield. Against the Tower Knight I withstood a hit but kept my sheild up and when he hit me again I was done. The attacks are slow, so I would tank a hit, then lower the sheild and my stamina would fly back to 100%, by the time he swung again I could tank a second hit. My buddy says Black Knights are super fucking hard in this game, idk if that's a boss or something, but I assume against a strong enemy with a huge sword you'll lose a ton of stamina by getting hit, due to the slow speed though you can recover it quickly enough to avoid being killed outright. Hope that helps someone.
snippet.textOriginal: OH AND HEY! Helpful tip I learned in Demons Souls which I assume will carry over: DON'T HOLD UP YOUR SHIELD AFTER A BLOCK!!!! Your stamina recovers much more slowly with the shield up. Pay attention or dodge out of the way and keep the shield down until you have 75-80% stamina back, otherwise another hit may break apart your stamina and cut through the shield. Against the Tower Knight I withstood a hit but kept my sheild up and when he hit me again I was done. The attacks are slow, so I would tank a hit, then lower the sheild and my stamina would fly back to 100%, by the time he swung again I could tank a second hit. My buddy says Black Knights are super fucking hard in this game, idk if that's a boss or something, but I assume against a strong enemy with a huge sword you'll lose a ton of stamina by getting hit, due to the slow speed though you can recover it quickly enough to avoid being killed outright. Hope that helps someone.

snippet.textDisplay:
The over-leveling tip is an interesting one. I finished Dark Souls Remastered a few days ago and started a new game+, I never played dark souls in the past this was my first time. Needless to say before going to kill Gwin, I spent like 5 hours soul farming in the painter world of ariamis and leveling up my character, almost every stat is 40 by the exception of resistance. So my character is like level 170 or so, which during the 1st play through when I went back to most of the areas I was so Over powered that I could run through blight town for example with only 1 estus flask and still got hit a bunch of times. 

When I started the new game I found out that the new game+ takes into account your soul level and other things when it comes down to setting up your enemies health and damage points. Now even the initial undeads do like 20% damage with one hit even me wearing hefty armor and the ring of steel and protection lol and sure I do get more souls per kill in the new play through but I need about 140,000 souls just to level up once....

I guess my point is if you are planning to play again (And you might want to to get all achievements) avoid over-leveling just take it casually

snippet.textDisplay:
This is a guide for Beginners - that means starting class matters!!! Sorcerer for example has 80 starting points at sl1 while pyromancer and wanderer start with 84 points at sl1. Sure those points are all in resistance. But 4 levels are 4 levels. That's why sorcerer has the highest max level 713 compared to pyro 709. And starting with 8 vitality and 8 endurance (medium roll) is not the easiest way. Pyro is probably (without skipping) the strongest starting class but casts at start extremly slow.

Beginner with soul experience: Pyro or Warrior (Quality). But my choice for a beginner would be Bandit! Bandit all the way ;)

snippet.textDisplay: These tips are over half a decade old, and I liked the video but here are my thoughts on your tips  (ive played every soulsborne game religiously).  Starting class definitely matters on your over all build. master key is a good tip. Playing online on a populated souls time frame is one of the best experiences you can have. using your souls when you can is  an okay tip, but an obvious one. Armor is just as important as mobility. Sticking to one weapon is a good idea early on, once you have enough resources it doesn't really matter if you switch to something else. On leveling up: this is why you're starting class does matter as it could help you have stats leveled up already and you could min max more. Resistance is spot on useless stat, you contradict yourself at this point in the video, when you just said armor didn't really matter. Last tip is solid, I see alot of noobs hording things because they don't know when they'll be in a bind, just use em. Over all solid video but you your self may be new to the series it seems.

snippet.textDisplay:
You made some very good points in this video, but I feel like there are 2 more that people should REALLY know about.
1. Just a Vinylic said, bows are very useful even if you don't have the stats to use them or even if they are not upgraded. Just being able to agro one enemy at a time can make a difficult area easy. But one thing I think needs to be know is that poison arrows are a godsend a lot of powerful enemy are susceptible to poison. For example, The Silver knights protecting the entry to the castle in Anor londo. You can poison them with a normal bow if you use poison arrows even though your arrows wont do any damage they will still inflict the poison damage. (I would  suggest using wooden arrows to fine tune your aim as poison arrow are fairly expensive in the early game and once you know where to aim then swap to the poison arrows and fipre away) Poison damage is slow but it is the safest way to do this area in NG. (For NG+ just use the DragonSlayer Greatbow and knock the one on the right off the ledge then haul ass!).

2. Most skills (AKA Str, dex, int, fth, Ect.) have what we call a Soft Cap and a Hard Cap. As you put points into a skill more and more you will begin to notice you will start to get less and less every time you level past a cretin point, this is called "Diminishing returns". Most skills (Not all) have the same Soft and Hard caps. 25 for the Soft cap and 50 for the Hard cap. What this means is, for Ex. leveling your Vit from 24 to 25 will get you (Just as an ex. I don't know the actual hp increase of the top of my head) 50Hp but from 25 to 26 now you would only get 25, and when you get past 50 the gains are almost unnoticeable. So when leveling you don't really ever want to go past 50 in one stat unless there is a requirement for a weapon/spell that you REALLY want. 

The next part only matters of you are planning to do PVP so if you don't like PVP you can stop reading now.

The soul level for general PVP is from 100-120. So this is the part where I have to disagree with Vinylic. Your starting class is VERY important when it comes to PVP, choosing the wrong class for the build that you want can break your chances of getting matches in PVP. If you have a specifc build that you want to use but are unsure on if you can get all the stats you need in order use the armor, weapons, and spell you need. I would suggest using a build calculator, (google "mugenmonkey", or the wiki has one it is like wiki.flextralife or something like that) you can plan every little detail for your build so you don't spend hours upon hours making a build and find out you can never use it for anything more than hosting in the forest because you are over leveled for the PVP meta.

But one thing I think needs to be know is that poison arrows are a godsend a lot of powerful enemy are susceptible to poison. For example, The Silver knights protecting the entry to the castle in Anor londo. You can poison them with a normal bow if you use poison arrows even though your arrows wont do any damage they will still inflict the poison damage. (I would  suggest using wooden arrows to fine tune your aim as poison arrow are fairly expensive in the early game and once you know where to aim then swap to the poison arrows and fipre away) Poison damage is slow but it is the safest way to do this area in NG. (For NG+ just use the DragonSlayer Greatbow and knock the one on the right off the ledge then haul ass!).

2. Most skills (AKA Str, dex, int, fth, Ect.) have what we call a Soft Cap and a Hard Cap. As you put points into a skill more and more you will begin to notice you will start to get less and less every time you level past a cretin point, this is called "Diminishing returns". Most skills (Not all) have the same Soft and Hard caps. 25 for the Soft cap and 50 for the Hard cap. What this means is, for Ex. leveling your Vit from 24 to 25 will get you (Just as an ex. I don't know the actual hp increase of the top of my head) 50Hp but from 25 to 26 now you would only get 25, and when you get past 50 the gains are almost unnoticeable. So when leveling you don't really ever want to go past 50 in one stat unless there is a requirement for a weapon/spell that you REALLY want. 

The next part only matters of you are planning to do PVP so if you don't like PVP you can stop reading now.

The soul level for general PVP is from 100-120. So this is the part where I have to disagree with Vinylic. Your starting class is VERY important when it comes to PVP, choosing the wrong class for the build that you want can break your chances of getting matches in PVP. If you have a specifc build that you want to use but are unsure on if you can get all the stats you need in order use the armor, weapons, and spell you need. I would suggest using a build calculator, (google "mugenmonkey", or the wiki has one it is like wiki.flextralife or something like that) you can plan every little detail for your build so you don't spend hours upon hours making a build and find out you can never use it for anything more than hosting in the forest because you are over leveled for the PVP meta.

snippet.textDisplay: Armor is most defiantly not a placebo in Ds1, in 2 or 3 maybe but 1 oh no. With some of the heaviest armors and shields in the game rolling becomes a non-issue. That said I’d only use it for select cases it’s still a good idea to learn rolling so I’d say aim for a mid roll build or at least a fat roll build so you have I-frames (mid roll actually has the same number of frames as fast roll btw just has recover frames at the end) but also have defended. Once you beat a boss called “sif the great grey wolf” you get his soul which can be made into artorias’ great sword or shield, the shield has the second highest stability in the game but has higher block percentages than the highest stability shield and can be used to block nearly indefinitely, pair with a spear to attack while blocking as well.

snippet.textDisplay:
Watching your video rn, 
Your point about armor, there's something you're heavily neglecting, Poise.
Poise is basically something I think all new players should know about and try to use since...
A.) Kinda especially needed in PvP if you're using any heavy weapon.
B.) You can heal while getting hit.
C.) Gives you a chance to make up for a poorly adjusted move if your poise isn't broken.
I know there's a ring for it and all, but not a lot of newer players are really going to find it unless they search about it.
Heavier armor does have it's immense use because of poise.

snippet.textDisplay:
Nah, first playthrough shouldn't have the master key. Progress through it normally the first time like a real man. Git Gud or Get lost. 
(I'm half joking. But for real, take Black Firebombs or Divine Blessing. They are the best for your first playthrough.) 
Farm for souls by killing enemies. Use Summons. Try using medium roll (it's easiest for newbies.). Keep an eye out for enemies resistance to elemental attacks (example: big fire enemy, don't use fire weapons/attacks. Simple). Get the claymore from the bridge with the red dragon, it has good scaling and is a very solid weapon that can take you to end game. Don't upgrade "resistance", It's trash; upgraded Dex or something useful. Etc etc
